text: 30 MHz is an Amsterdam-based software company

who set out to build an analytics 
and management platform for smart devices.
They never dreamed they would end up in agriculture.

We started with a cloud
 infrastructure model platform.
We developed this on AWS.

I'm Jasper Geurtsen, Co-Founder 
and Head of Hardware Department in 30 MHz.

The first few years we focused on building 
the product and finding our industry.

My name is Flavia Paganelli, 
I am Co-Founder at 30 MHz and former CTO.

We knew that we wanted to combine 
our strong AWS infrastructure
with wireless sensors to digitalize some process,
but we didn't know what process yet.
30 MHz found the ideal match for that combination

in the agricultural industry, 
specifically greenhouses and indoor farms.
We realized that we were culturally a very good fit.

And then, we decided to focus on building the product 
knowing that we would add value to the space.

With the global population predicted 
to reach 9.1 billion by 2050,

the world's food production 
needs to increase by at least 70%.

Meaning more farmers grow
 more food for more people
while not taxing our planet's precious resources.

We set out to make a data-driven technology 
for any farmers in the world, for any states.

We knew when we came into 
the agriculture field that we had technology

that could really help low-tech farmers 
bridge the gap with high-tech farmers.

The original 30 MHz platform
 culled and analyzed data

from infield monitoring devices, 
allowing farmers to remotely monitor

and manage much of what
 happened in their greenhouses.

What you see is that farmers are 
cultivating ever-increasing plots of land

and with the script of predictive analytics, 
we can help them
manage these areas more effectively.
I'm Daam Rutten, I'm a data scientist working for 30MHz.

In the early days, teams had to 
troubleshoot outages, loss of data,
and found the monitoring system difficult to scale.

So we had to re-design part of our architecture 
to make our gateways
run autonomously.

But we saw this as an opportunity 
to drop some of our software
and start using AWS IoT.
With the support of the AWS prototype team,

we managed to integrate 
AWS Greengrass into our gateways,

and this way we loosened the boundary 
between the edge and the cloud network

and really make this flexible, 
and we get additional features

like offline buffering, 
so when the connection drops,

then Greengrass will store the data for us, 
and when the connection is recovered,
it will send out the missing time.
My name is Amir Majlesi.

I look after AWS prototyping activities
in development at Nordics.

We collaborated with the 30 MHz team 
in a hands-on rapid prototyping engagement,
helping them modernize their architecture and build
a serverless smart agriculture solution.

We co-developed a working prototype which was
 customized to their business environment in just 3 weeks.

The new prototype solved 
the device management and connectivity issues,

and helped 30 MHz automate 
the provisioning of gateways.
It also added capabilities such as over-the-air updates
and advanced security measures to protect data.

In 2019, the team participated
in the Autonomous Greenhouse Challenge,
sponsored by Wageningen University & Research.

The goal of the Greenhouse Challenge 
was to autonomously manage

a greenhouse for 6 months. 
We were cultivating tomatoes.

The experience pushed 30 MHz to look closer
 at how they could bring this type of data analytics
and machine learning to real growers.

And I think it was the introduction 
to the challenge that also introduced us to

the possibilities for autonomous growing
for actual greenhouses.

30 MHz sought to develop a solution 
that combined the data monitoring software
and the data collecting hardware with machine learning.

This machine learning technology would 
enable growers to make real-time decisions

on climate and irrigation, 
creating optimal growing conditions for crops.

The 30 MHz team had highly specialized expertise
in digital agriculture and data science.

The port of engagements really 
builds upon these existing skills

and enabled the team to develop a new 
machine learning pipeline with Amazon SageMaker.

The AWS team helped 30 MHz analyze the data, 
build and deploy the machine learning models

for inference, and automate the machine learning process
from beginning to end.
We implemented the architecture in 2 parts.
Model training and inference.

First, we fetched the existing 30 MHz codes
from their code repository.

We trained this model with Amazon SageMaker, 
using specific data sets from each grower.

Once training is done,
SageMaker stores the model artifacts in an S3 bucket.

The next step is to evaluate the model performance 
to check if the accuracy is sufficient enough.
After it passes, the model is deployed.

Once deployed, the model is now ready 
for inference with incoming sensor data
collected from customer fields using AWS Greengrass.

So one of our customers is 
an IPM consultant

and he has been using the 30 MHz platform
to really look into the data
with grower groups on situations

where pest and diseases might increase 
and analyzing this micro-climate data,
including the crop log data to really see situations
or conditions that may explain these kinds of situations.

For these grower groups, 
understanding and visualizing this data

on the disease management is really helping them
to push back the infection.

They not only save money, but it's maybe 
more important that they're really able to

leave out some chemical solutions
that might otherwise
be necessary to really push back the disease.

So we envisioned our technology being available 
everywhere in the world at a fraction of the cost
of climate computer systems.

And this will dramatically lower the costs
of running a greenhouse.
This can happen everywhere in the world.

The 30 MHz prototype is currently being tested
by 8 pilot growers,

with the hopes of scaling up to hundreds, 
even thousands, of growers in the near future.

The insights and information
that this technology gives to our customers
can be life-changing.

The collaboration with AWS prototyping
has been key for this,
because we have been able to build and test fast

and also create solutions which are 
scalable and reliable from the beginning.

The 30 MHz team continues to look to the future, 
refining and expanding the capabilities
while keeping the technology easy to use.

I think one of the things that we've experienced
is that it's possible to have
real-time autonomous control.

The main challenge, however, is to incorporate
real-time feedback from the crop,

which we still aren't able to measure, 
or at least measure to the extent that we'd like.

Today, 30 MHz has 35 employees, 
and services over 330 customers
across 30 countries and counting.

30 MHz wants to be the leader
 who brings the infrastructure

and information to growers to allow them, 
and the whole industry, to advance
at a much faster pace.

And in this way, they can make better use
of resources and feed the world.
